channel.title: Health | Mail Online
channel.description: Check out the latest health news, articles, advice and information for you and your family from the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday.

item.title: Eating plenty of fruit and veg DOES help us live longer
item.description: Scientists from the Scripps Research Institute in San Diego found that antioxidants can keep a vital organ called the thymus healthy by stopping age-related damage in its tracks.

item.title: White bread and pasta 'may increase the risk of depression': Blood sugar spikes caused by highly refined carbs can trigger bad moods and anxiety
item.description: However women who ate more fibre, whole grains, vegetables and fruits (but not fruit juice) had a lower risk of the mental illness, say the researchers, from the National Institutes of Health.

item.title: NHS may have been overcharged 'millions' for common drug by Pfizer and Flynn Pharma
item.description: The Competition and Markets Authority is investigating whether Pfizer and Flynn Pharma used their position to charge ‘excessive and unfair’ prices for phenytoin sodium capsules.

item.title: Why it IS easier to work out to music - it dulls the pain
item.description: Listening to our favourite music makes the brain release natural painkilling chemicals called opioids – the same family of drugs as heroin and morphine, found research from McGill University.

item.title: Benefits of weight-loss surgery only last 5 years
item.description: While many obese patients lose weight in the first year after bariatric operations, experts at Tel Aviv University say after five years many begin to regain the pounds they initially shed.

item.title: Why women feel more pain than men in break-ups: But they do get over it faster and move on
item.description: The tears, the anger, the tub of ice cream – it’s the classic picture of a woman going through a break-up. Scientists believe that women actually suffer more emotionally than men after break-up.

item.title: Women with breast implants are THREE times more likely to commit suicide
item.description: Women who get breast implants may already have psychiatric problems to do with lower self-esteem or body image disorders, according to researchers from the Vanderbilt University Medical Center.

item.title: Secret to getting a flat stomach lies in your BRAIN as STRESS triggers gut problems
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Bloating can be triggered by anything from fluctuating hormones to eating reheated pasta - or even a glass of water. But stress could be having the biggest effect of all, say doctors.

item.title: Can a cosmetic treatment make you 'scientifically beautiful'?
item.description: Emily Adair, 30, underwent the procedure earlier this year, and paid £999 for dermal fillers injections in her nose and chin. She said she cried with joy after seeing the results.

item.title: How being stressed can ruin your diet
item.description: Brain scans revealed when a person is stressed they show patterns associated with a loss of self-control, scientists at the University of Zurich noted.

item.title: Made In Chelsea's Fabian Bolin reveals he has beaten leukaemia in five week
item.description: Fabian Bolin 28, who is also known for his role in web sci-fi show Kosmos, was diagnosed with leukaemia, cancer of the blood, on July 1 and admitted: 'There is a risk that I will not survive.'

item.title: Cancer survival rates in England see more patients dying than any Western country
item.description: Patients in England are more likely to die from six of the most common types of the illness than those in Australia, Canada, Sweden and Norway, according to researchers (file photo).

item.title: How Kybella injections 'will shrink your double chin'
item.description: The drug - which costs $300 (£192) per injection - was developed by experts at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Centre in Dallas.

item.title: Ovarian cancer patients given a 'glimmer of hope' with new drug
item.description: The drugs rationing watchdog Nice is considering whether to make olaparaib - which extends ovarian cancer patients by an average 11 months - to women who've had three rounds of chemotherapy.

item.title: Rise of patients in 40s suffering from dementia as researchers warn of 'silent epidemic'
item.description: Researchers from Bournemouth University have warned that dementia is often striking those considered young adding they believe pollution from cars and aeroplanes is to blame.

item.title: What your FACE says about your health: 7 warning signs to watch out for
item.description: Dark rings around the neck might indicate an increased risk of type 2 diabetes, while acne on the chin might be a sign of polycystic ovarian syndrome, according to experts.

item.title: The women driven mad with rage by HUNGER: Hormones affecting appetites and moods can lead to hunger-induced anger
item.description: According to dietitians, while some of us feel lethargic or cannot concentrate without food, a significant number react with rage.

item.title: Internet, movies and books saying how sex 'ought to be' putting couples under pressure
item.description: Many couples find the steamy antics in Fifty Shades of Grey more intimidating than inspiring, a new survey for Relate, the relationship charity, found.

item.title: Heart risk for slow thinkers: Over-75s with the poorest mental agility found to be 85% more likely to suffer an attack than those in the highest group
item.description: People with poor thinking skills may be at higher risk of heart attack or stroke, a study has shown. Scientists monitored almost 4,000 individuals with an average age of 75 for three years.

item.title: Fat toddlers will be sent to weekly weight loss class
item.description: GPs and health visitors are being urged to send obese youngsters to the sessions as soon as they can walk, typically from 18 months, where they will be given raw fruit and vegetables (file photo).

item.title: Can Vicks Vaporub give you perfect summer feet?
item.description: With the help of Dr Tariq Khan, consultant podiatrist at London's Wilbraham Place Practice, CLAIRE COLEMAN looks at the science behind some of the most popular tips.
item.media:description: Close Up of Woman's Legs Feet and Calfs

item.title: Yono earphones help women get pregnant by measuring best time to concieve
item.description: The $99 (£64) Yono device can monitor a woman’s basal body temperature, or BBT, which increases slightly in the days before a woman is at her most fertile.

item.title: Skin cancer hope as trigger that turns melanoma cells into killers identified
item.description: When melanoma cells come into contact with a certain molecule, it causes them to travel down the skin into the bloodstream, making them deadly, according to researchers form Tel Aviv University.

item.title: Your gastric band could make you have lower alcohol tolerance
item.description: Scientists at Washington University in St Louis found women who consumed two drinks after the operation had blood-alcohol contents similar to those who had four drinks but hadn't had the surgery.

item.title: The anti-ageing MIND diet that halves your risk of dementia
item.description: The MIND diet, developed by experts at the Rush University Medical Centre, involves eating wholegrains, vegetables, lean meats, nuts and fish but avoiding red meat and dairy and processed foods.

item.title: Six children families are sick 45 weeks a year compared to childless ones
item.description: Childless couples get cold and flu three to four weeks a year, while this jumps to 45 weeks for families with six or more children, Utah Centre for Clinical and Translational Science experts found.

item.title: Holiday cocktails could be making you fat as calories in top drinks revealed
item.description: An infographic by party organisers Eventa shows how easy it is to bust your bikini diet with alcoholic beach drinks which are packed with the same number of calories as fatty fast food.

item.title: Could hackers target your life-saving medical device?
item.description: The US Food and Drug Administration and Department of Homeland Security have warned infusion pumps which deliver drugs to patients contain 'security flaws' and can be hacked.

item.title: Surgeons remove 12cm WORM from a woman's eyelid after parasitic infection
item.description: Doctors at the Aster Hospital, Dubai, removed the 12cm worm from the 55-year-old woman's eyelid. They diagnosed her as suffering a parasitic infection called dirofilariasis.

item.title: Your first child really CAN put you off having more
item.description: Scientists in Germany and Canada found some couples perceive a drop in their happiness in the first year of having a baby, greater than that caused by unemployment, divorce or the death of a partner.

item.title: Tracey Cox reveals the three fears that are ruining women's sex lives
item.description: Our sexpert says that many women are so anxious about their bodies and lack of libido that they can't enjoy themselves in the bedroom but here she explains why there is nothing to worry about.

item.title: The Pill could protect against womb cancer for five decades
item.description: Oxford academics calculate that the contraceptive has prevented around 200,000 cases of the illness in the Western world in the past decade.

item.title: Are women becoming the unhealthy sex?
item.description: Mother of two Daloni Carlisle, 51, from Sevenoaks, Kent, regrets putting the demands of her busy life before her health.
item.media:description: FML - Daloni Carlisle..Feature about how women are becoming the unhealthier sex - delaying routine smears, not going to the docs and drinking more. Daloni was madly juggling things and delayed going to the doc for months, She then found out she had advanced womb cancer in January...Photo credit : Chris Winter

item.title: Teen cannabis use 'NOT linked to depression or lung cancer in later life'
item.description: Psychologists at the University of Pittsburgh were 'surprised there was no difference in health outcomes regardless of how often men used cannabis as a teenager.

item.title: Nursery school teacher cries 'CRYSTAL' tears due to mystery condition
item.description: Laura Ponce, 35, of Lins, Brazil, suffers from a bizarre condition which means hard, white plaques form in her eyes, which she has to remove manually. Sometimes she has to remove up to 30 a day.

item.title: Sheffield teen's PMS headaches were actually 'a result of a stroke'
item.description: Georgia Smith, 13, from Sheffield, was diagnosed with hydrocephalus - a build-up of fluid on the brain - and doctors warned she had likely suffered a stroke after enduring painful migraines for months.

item.title: Noise during operations found to be causing doctors communication problems
item.description: Surgeons were found to be five times more likely to have to repeat requests for medical instruments when a soundtrack was played in theatre.

item.title: Progeria sufferer, 18, to undergo new drug trial in the hopes of finding a cure
item.description: Ana Rochelle Pondare, from Manila, Philippines, was diagnosed with progeria when she was five-years-old. At 18, Ana is already one of the oldest progeria patients in the world.

item.title: Kellogg's Corn Flakes invented to stop masturbation and sexual desire
item.description: Corn Flakes were invented by John Harvey Kellogg in the 19th century. Mr Kellogg created the plain cereal to prevent people masturbating - which he believed caused 39 illnesses including acne.

item.title: Eating hot food three times a week 'reduces the risk of early death from cancer'
item.description: Scientists from Oxford and Havard universities suspect that capsaicin — a chemical contained in chili peppers — has anti-obesity, antioxidant, anti-inflammation and cancer fighting properties.

item.title: 17-stone mother drank NINE cups of green tea a day and drop eight dress sizes
item.description: Mother-of-two Samantha Rees, 30, from Salford, Greater Manchester, drank the herbal brew all day long to shrink from 17st 5lb to 9st 4lb. The obese claims assessor dropped eight dress sizes in a year.

item.title: British binge-drinkers ignore alcohol guidelines with limits deemed irrelevant
item.description: Many Britons work hard all week and then drink to excess at the weekend, making the 30-year-old 'unit' limits for safe levels of 'regular drinking' irrelevant, a landmark study claims.

item.title: Miranda Kerr shares her fitness and alkaline-based diet secrets
item.description: The Australian-born model, 32, revealed the details of her demanding daily exercise regime and her tricks to keeping junk food cravings at bay in an interview with Your Fitness magazine.

item.title: Boston University's 3D map reveals tiny connections between cells
item.description: Harvard University researchers hope the map could be used to identify unusual connections between brain cells that could shed light on disorders such as bipolar and depression.

item.title: What happens one hour after drinking a can of Diet coke revealed
item.description: The latest graphic about the effects of the soda has been compiled by The Renegade Pharmacist, a blog run by a former UK pharmacist Niraj Naik and includes the four main effects after drinking it.

item.title: Teenager overcomes crippling scoliosis spinal condition to become a model
item.description: Tamara Shape, 18, from Chelmsford, Essex, was diagnosed with scoliosis, a painful disease which results in abnormal twisting of the spine. She spent years in agony and took painkillers daily.

item.title: Test that could predict breast cancer nine years before it strikes
item.description: The team from Imperial College London found that women who went on to develop breast cancer had low levels of a chemical called methyl in their white blood cells make-up compared to others.

item.title: Niall Kirkpatrick warns of unlicensed fillers danger on Botched Up Bodies
item.description: Niall Kirkpatrick, a top surgeon who appears on Channel 5 show Botched Up Bodies, has used an appearance to warn of the dangers after treating Hanna Costea, 33, who was left with a lopsided lip.

item.title: Farmer survives septic shock after hearing his wife's nagging at hospital
item.description: Gill Osgerby, 32, from East Riding, gave her husband Will, 42, a piece of her mind as he lay unconscious battling deadly sepsis. Doctors were stunned when he made a recovery six days later.

item.title: Men who have casual sex 'produce better quality sperm and have faster orgasms'
item.description: Scientists at The College of Wooster in Ohio found the quantity, structure and movement of a man's sperm improved when he was stimulated by a new female.

item.title: Scunthorpe man whose heart stopped for an HOUR is revived by 13 electric shocks
item.description: David Lines, 35, from Scunthorpe, technically 'died' for 55 minutes after a cardiac arrest. Doctors said that if a person's heart stops for 30 minutes, they have less than a 10 per cent change of survival.

item.title: Great Yarmouth man who hadn't exercised until he was 38 becomes a body builder
item.description: Nuno Viera from Great Yarmouth found himself putting on unnecessary weight and became depressed after downing over four litres of coke a day, making him unfit, miserable and fat.

item.title: Weight-loss Thin Ice CLOTHING 'hacks' your metabolism, makers claim
item.description: The Thin Ice clothing line, created by Toronto-based personal trainer Adam Paulin, lowers the user's body temperature which triggers a warming response that burns calories.

item.title: Mother shaves her head to create a wig for alopecia-suffering daughter
item.description: Jo Green, 41, from Bournemouth, grew her hair for three years and dyed it blonde before having it shaved off to create a wig for her daughter Lauren, 17, who suffers alopecia.

item.title: Face map your acne to reveal what the position of your blemishes says about YOU
item.description: Traditional Chinese medicine and wellbeing expert John Tsagaris, from London, tells FEMAIL what acne on different areas of your face can tell you about your lifestyle and the easy fixes you can make.

item.title: Esme De Silva forced to take 6 months off work because of her excessive SWEATING
item.description: Esme De Silva, 25 from Maidenhead, Berkshire, developed anxiety after suffering hyperhidrosis- excessive sweating - for years. She was finally cured by an overnight antiperspirant.

item.title: Up to 10,000 patients face 'being stripped of cancer drugs'
item.description: In meetings held behind closed doors last week, officials discussed removing up to 37 treatments from the Cancer Drugs Fund list because it is running out of money.

item.title: 2-in-1 operation to banish blind spots and stop cataracts
item.description: Michael Mears, 75, a retired builder from Winchester, underwent an innovative technique to treat it, as he tells DIANA PILKINGTON.
item.media:description: BADPMK High contrast black white close up of a womans eyes coloured green

item.title: How to reduce redness and pain of sunburn
item.description: Here, Dr Justine Hextall, a consultant dermatologist with Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Trust, explains how to reduce redness and pain.
item.media:description: Sunscreen / sun tan lotion sun drawing on woman back. Girl in bikini sitting on beach in sunlight.; Shutterstock ID 100144169

item.title: It's not Viagra he needs... it's testosterone
item.description: Sexual health specialist, Professor Geoffrey Hackett, believes as much as half of Viagra prescribed to men will not work on its own because their real problem is low testosterone.

item.title: Boost your iron with a glass of red wine and Bombay mix
item.description: Most people don't get enough iron from their diets. The nutrient is vital for health, helping our bodies make red blood cells, which carry oxygen around the body.

item.title: Jessica Sepel shares her journey in her latest book The Healthy Life
item.description: Sydney nutritionist Jessica Sepel knows how it feels to struggle with diets and food, but in her book The Healthy Life, Miss Sepel gives a 10-step guide to finding inner health and healing

item.title: Infections that wreck summer for millions of women
item.description: For a huge number of women, summer is blighted by the agony of UTIs. Liz Fletcher, 31, from Cambridge, has suffered them from the age of 13.
item.media:description: Liz Fletcher from Cambridge. 30.7.2015. ..Liz suffers from repeated urinary tract infections and has done since the age of 13. She still gets them but less often now, and has learned to manage them and identified triggers...

item.title: Pear juice can reduce effects of a night's drinking by up to a fifth
item.description: Australian government scientists say eating a whole pear helps increase concentration, reduces memory loss and even decreases the amount of alcohol in your bloodstream.

item.title: Men who become dads before they are aged 25 'run a higher risk of dying in middle age'
item.description: Researchers at the University of Helsinki in Finland suggest that the stress of fatherhood can lead to health problems later in life for those who have their first child in their early twenties.

item.title: Fussy eating and being picky with food linked to greater levels of anxiety
item.description: The study by researchers in the U.S. found that those who were most selective in what they ate were twice as likely as normal eaters to have a diagnosis of depression or suffer from anxiety.

item.title: How 'hippy crack' can lead to BLINDNESS
item.description: Opthalmologist and laser eye surgeon David Allamby, clinical director of London's Focus clinic, says the surge in people using laughing gas could lead to a 'sight loss epidemic' in future years.

item.title: Idleness 'will end up killing as many people as smoking': Study finds quarter of adults don't manage to do 30 minutes of exercise each week
item.description: In its assessment of sport in Britain, the Department for Culture Media and Sport warned that lack of exercise kills as many people as smoking.

item.title: Paper cup that helps beat asthma attacks could replace spacers
item.description: The paper cup is designed to replace spacers - the large plastic cylinders used to make sure that patients inhale the right amount of medication into their lungs.

item.title: How to get Rachel McAdams' trim waist
item.description: We reveal how to get the physiques of the stars. This week: Rachel McAdams' waist.

item.title: Blister on diabetic comedian Colin Leggo's toe that led to him losing his leg
item.description: Colin Leggo (his real name) had his right leg amputated from the mid-calf and this month he'll be at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, performing an act devoted to this experience.

item.title: Heart attacks cut five more years from women's lives than men's
item.description: Previously doctors thought that men and women had roughly similar prospects after a heart attack and this research is the first to take into account women’s longer average life expectancy.

item.title: How wasp stings can trigger heart attacks
item.description: Around three in 100 healthy adults are known to have an allergy to insect stings or bites.
item.media:description: BT1BDK Yarn of wool in heart shape symbol

item.title: Can you ever get back a lost sense of smell?
item.description: A reader's wife lost her sense of taste and smell after a persistent cough. They were told it could be permanent. Dr Scurr advises.
item.media:description: early 20th century --- A young boy wears a clothespin on his nose to simulate the feeling of a head cold. --- Image by ¬© Corbis

item.title: Children as young as TWO sent to NHS 'fat camps' to tackle obesity crisis
item.description: More than 700 children have been referred to the paediatric weight management scheme run by NHS Lothian in Scotland, to help tackle rising rates of childhood obesity.

item.title: Botched breast reduction leaves woman with a rotting nipple that almost killed her
item.description: Sue McManus, 54, from Lancashire, was forced to have emergency surgery to save her life after a routine breast reduction resulted in a necrotic - rotting - nipple that left her dangerously ill.

item.title: Boy died from meningitis after 999 call handler told mum to call 111
item.description: Sofia Mohammed called the emergency services after her son, Yusuf Abdismad, stopped breathing and was put through to a London Ambulance emergency medical dispatcher.

item.title: Is marriage the key to beating alcoholism?
item.description: Scientists at the universities of Missouri and Arizona found tying the knot causes dramatic reductions in the amount of alcohol people drink, even among those with severe addictions.

item.title: Cardio vs weights? Personal trainer reveals best exercise for you
item.description: Personal trainer Grace Lavinia explores the pros and cons of cardio training versus lifting weights, adding the perfect workout regime incorporates both, as well as HIIT training.

item.title: Rhiley Bennett dies of rare cancer just 11 months after first falling ill
item.description: Rhiley Bennett, three, of Milton Keynes died battling an AT/RT tumour which attacks the central nervous system. Her mother Kim Bennett, 27, claims there were 'fatal errors' in her care.

item.title: Chipping Sodbury beautician paralysed after falling down the stairs
item.description: Kate Sell, 43, from Chipping Sodbury, has been left paralysed from the chest down after falling down the stairs when sleep walking. She faces an anxious wait to see if it is permanent.

item.title: Brierley Hill woman says a single STITCH in her cervix saved her son's life
item.description: Nicola Richards, 27, from Brierley Hill, West Midlands, had a stitch sewn in to her cervix when she was 14 weeks pregnant to keep it closed, and prevent her son Jesse being born prematurely.

item.title: How leafy vegetables and carrots can give you an attractive glow
item.description: Forget expensive make-up and miracle potions – the best way to achieve that irresistible magnetism towards the opposite sex may to be to eat your greens.

item.title: Early warning test for pancreas cancer are simple and cheap
item.description: Researchers in London have identified three proteins which give an early and accurate warning sign of pancreatic cancer.

item.title: New end-of-life care rules are 'worse than the death pathway'
item.description: Professor Patrick Pullicino, a leading critic of the controversial Liverpool Care Pathway which was phased out in 2014, said the new replacement proposals mimic many of the LCP's key problems.

item.title: Suicide courts bill set to be put before MPs headed by Labour's Robert Marris
item.description: The private members bill promoted by Labour MP Robert Marris (pictured) is the sixth attempt in 12 years to push a law through Parliament to liberalise the law on suicide.

item.title: UK hospitals have sixth worst record for leaving 'foreign bodies' after surgery
item.description: A new report shows the UK's rate for failing to remove 'foreign bodies' is 5.5 cases per 100,000 people, three times that of Poland, with 1.9 cases, and twice that of Slovenia, at 2.9 cases.

item.title: Liverpool woman chewed gum for 4 hours a day and needs an operation to fix jaw
item.description: Claire Embleton, from Liverpool, could be left with scars after her chewing gum habit wrecked the joints at the side of her mouth leaving her unable to open her mouth more than 1cm.

item.title: Brits are not getting enough Vitamin D from sunlight
item.description: Government health advisers are proposing a dietary intake of 10 micrograms of vitamin D per day for everyone age over one year in a bid to combat the gloomy British winters.

item.title: ASK DR ELLIE: I can't shake the pain after my flu vaccine
item.description: The aim of a flu vaccination is to prevent debilitating illnesses, but there is always a risk that preventative medicine will give you side effects, writes DR ELLIE CANNON.

item.title: Grandmother with AMD can see again thanks to new 'Hubble telescope' eye lens
item.description: Four years ago, Irene da Silva, from Plymouth, was told by specialists that there was no cure or effective treatment that would halt the progress of her eye disease.

item.title: Women struck by life-threatening liver disease are told it's menopause by GPs
item.description: Wendy Wheat, from Nottingham, had to wait years for doctors to realise what was wrong. The 43-year-old spent three years suffering from severe exhaustion, extreme itchiness and joint pain.

item.title: Kids who are popular at school become losers as adults
item.description: Researchers found teens who were 'cool' at school were far more likely to struggle as an adult, and were at higher risk of falling into a life of alcohol, drugs and crime. Pictured, James Dean.
item.media:description: FILM. 'REBEL WITHOUT A CAUSE'. (1956) Picture shows James Dean with Natalie Wood. ACTORS

item.title: A cup of coffee a day could stave off Alzheimer's
item.description: A cup of coffee a day really can stave off Alzheimer's disease, say scientists. But having two or more cups or never touching the brew puts you at risk of the condition that causes early memory problems.

item.title: Mobile phones ARE linked to cancer, scientist claims
item.description: Dr Igor Yakymenko, from from the The National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, says the data is 'a clear sign of the real risks to human health'. But official guidance says the evidence is inconclusive.

item.title: Student who lost ends of her fingers AND toes to meningitis urges others to get vaccinated
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Sophie Royce, from Reigate, was diagnosed with meningococcal W septicaemia at 21. Today a new programme for 17 and 18-year-olds is rolled out to get them vaccinated.

item.title: Cutting benefits for drunks and the obese isn't cruel, it's kind, says Dr Max
item.description: You have the right to live your life how you please. But you can’t expect others to provide indefinite financial support so that you can make self-destructive choices, writes DR MAX PEMBERTON.

item.title: Doctors operated on baby before she was born in pioneering operation
item.description: Michelle Cannon, 31, from Doncaster, had been advised to have an abortion after receiving the devastating news that her unborn daughter had a rare and usually deadly condition.

item.title: Surgeons 'perform BETTER when listening to their favourite songs'
item.description: Scientists at the University of Texas found when plastic surgeons listened to their favourite songs, their surgical technique and efficiency when closing incisions improved.

item.title: Healthista's Anna Magee reveals 10 things to do to stave off dementia
item.description: With an estimated 44 million people across the world suffering with Alzheimer's and the prospect of that figure doubling by 2050, Anna Magee reveals the simple steps we can take to ward off the disease.
